Definition: Private sector digital support
Opportunistic: Growing technology penetration in key sectors
Systematic: Cross-sector collaboration. Seed financing.
Differentiating: Digital coordinated across sectors. Venture financing.
Transformational: Digital industry. Enacting digital responsibility standards

Definition: Banking, non-banking, access to venture capital, crowdfunding etc.
Opportunistic: Supported by Angel ecosytem
Systematic: Significant Venture Captial support
Differentiating: Traditional Banking available
Transformational: R&D Grants and foreign Venture Capital available

Definition: Digital technology norms, transparency requirements, methods of reporting
Opportunistic: EU GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation)-type Adherence
Systematic: Structure for committment to positive social economic, technological and environmental impact
Differentiating: Public security, privacy, hiring audits/ Transparency Reports
Transformational: Open Data + Transparent Algorithms + Inclusive Hiring Practices

Definition: Strength of legal rights, time to start a business, ease of doing business
Basic: Starting a business requires lengthy paperwork, legal complexity, and numerous fees
Opportunistic: Easy to set up an office with construction, electricity and internet
Systematic: Businesses can be formed quickly. Protections exist for online businesses.
Differentiating: Taxation, Banking and Employment are easy to do
Transformational: Digital contract enforcement. Government services all accessible instantly online.

Definition: Payments, ERP & CRM adoption, tech adoption, marketplaces
Opportunistic: Businesses operate via chat
Systematic: Key sectors operate using a variety of digital tools for management
Differentiating: Most sectors operate using a variety of digital tools for management
Transformational: Majority of companies are digital by default

Definition: Foundational digital catalysts are overarching digital systems which can accelerate progress in all parts of the digital transformation
Basic: Siloed to operate independently and/or missing key elements entirely
Opportunistic: Partially synchronized to operate together
Systematic: Fully synchronized to operate together while protecting user privacy and control
Differentiating: Using open standards and ensuring vendor and technology neutrality
Transformational: Ensuring universal coverage for individuals from birth to death without discrimination

Definition: Open government data and private data, such as registries
Opportunistic: Some data is shared via image-based PDFs
Systematic: Data is shared via machine-readable PDFs and Spreadsheets
Differentiating: There is a standard for publishing data that is increasingly adhered to. Majority of data is available.
Transformational: Public data is published in a structured way by default that is API accessible

Definition: National digital legal identity system covering the entire population; possibility to use for stakeholders to access services and for transactions
Opportunistic: Records digitized
Systematic: Records digitalized
Differentiating: Records integrated with government and business services
Transformational: Federated / self-sovereign ID system with multiple validators

Definition: Digital payments ecosystem which includes digital financial service providers, digital financial services, provider support services and enablers (e.g. platforms, agents, processors), regional and global interoperability
Basic: Traditional banking. This is the main means of managing money and payments through the 19th century centered around bank accounts and paying through cash or checks
Opportunistic: Introduction of digital access to bank accounts. This is the digitization of traditional banking with debit and credit cards, and online banking to process cashless payments
Systematic: Prepaid accounts and mobile money. This includes prepaid payment cards, apps and mobile money accounts which may not require a bank account
Differentiating: Decoupling payment systems. This includes digital wallets where payment is initiated in a connected device, and the money remains in a bank or prepaid account
Transformational: Decoupling currency account. This includes digital wallets where money is converted into a private or local currency available only on the device or application

Definition: National Institutional digital support
Opportunistic: First digital initiatives in siloes. Limited political support.
Systematic: Shared vision and strategy. Vocally encouraged.
Differentiating: Embedded in decision-making. Codified in administrative acts.
Transformational: Culture of innovation. Codified in legislation.

Definition: Strategy/ programmes for digitalisation of most important public services incl. in e-participation, standards for service design and delivery, overarching data governance framework, open government data strategy, data center strategy
Basic: Services are done in paper form
Opportunistic: Initial digitization
Systematic: Initial digitalization
Differentiating: Adoption of and adherence to the Principles For Digital Development
Transformational: Creating replicable Digital Public Goods

Definition: System-based approach to ICT procurement and funding strategy/budget for digital transformation
Basic: Digital budgets are collected from funds allocated to various departments
Opportunistic: Departments allocate digital budgets annually
Systematic: Digital is dependent on annual budget negotiations
Differentiating: Digital is supported by multi-year allocation of capital
Transformational: Multi-year budgets include funding for both operations and capital expenditures

Definition: KPIs for tracking
Opportunistic: Projects are maintained for problems not improved with benefits
Systematic: User experience testing and metrics are tracked across digital projects after launch
Differentiating: Alpha-Beta-Live approach is standard with standard metrics for tracking success & impact
Transformational: Standard is operating publicly with data and information accessible

Definition: Soft and Hard tools to enable digital
Basic: Limited infrastructure. Access to undersea internet cables.
Opportunistic: Growing internet service provider & mobile networks.
Systematic: Growing connectivity. Limited developer & business ecosystems.
Differentiating: Affordable connectivity. Strong supply chains. Growing tech hubs.
Transformational:
Universal broadband. 
IoT. Inclusive ecosystems.

Definition: Availability, affordability and quality of broadband internet access, mobile internet, mobile services and devices, electricity etc.
Opportunistic: ISP Broadband Urban. Mobile coverage rurual.
Systematic: ISP Broadband Main Cities, wealthy areas. Mobile broadband coverage main cities.
Differentiating: Universal 4G. ISP broadband in cities affordable & easy access
Transformational: Universal mobile broadband. Universal ISP broadband. affordable, easy access. secure

Definition: No citizen left behind in digital support
Basic: Limited literacy. Cultural aversion to technology.
Opportunistic: Limited digital literacy. Consumption-focused. Deep digital divide.
Systematic: Growing digital literacy. Production increases. Technology embraced.
Differentiating: High levels of digital literacy. Online financial transactions.
Transformational: Limited digital divide.

Definition: Trust in digital technologies, attitudes towards entrepreneurial risks, social norms for use and ownership of internet and technology
Opportunistic: Digital is perceived as risky
Systematic: Digital is perceived as innovation
Differentiating: Digital/ STEM education is prioritized
Transformational: Digital is perceived as a fundamental skill for society

Definition: Ability to use digital technology of all parts of society (all regions, age groups, genders); particularly of traditionally marginalized groups of society (refugees and migrants, women and youth, persons with disabilities and special needs, older people,
Basic: Knowledge of how to access digital tools
Opportunistic: Knowledge of how to use digital tools for personal use
Systematic: Knowledge of how to access digital tools for professional use
Differentiating: Understanding of how to identify and use new digital tools
Transformational: Knowledge of how to create digital tools and/or automations

Definition: Understanding and mitigating harm inflicted by digital such as addiction, cyber bullying, disinformation, physical impacts
Opportunistic: Reducing physical security risks and online harassment
Systematic: Access to health services
Differentiating: Digital addiction monitoring
Transformational: Tracking and mitigating disinformation

Definition: Use of digital technology by different level so society, financial inclusiveness, e-commerce activity, information access trends
Opportunistic: Minimal digital divides in mobile
Systematic: Significant computer penetration
Differentiating: Minimal digital divides with computers
Transformational: Digital economy positively impacting average citizen

Definition: Legal and policy digital support
Opportunistic: Regulations support fundamentals.
Systematic: Initial policies and laws established.
Differentiating: Regulations enable innovation. Transparently online.
Transformational: Foundations enabled. Regulations integrated.

Definition: Security standards and risk management, cybercrime, content filtering, breach notifications
Opportunistic: Cybercrime definitions
Systematic: Cybersecurity regulation such as reporting requirements
Differentiating: Encryption and anonymity standards. Central regulator.
Transformational: Decentralization (eg Bug Bounties)

Definition: Standards/guidelines for emerging technology and specifically the use of artificial intelligence
Opportunistic: Terms & conditions of transactions, transparent/secure payment, and data protection
Systematic: Dispute resolution and redress and the right to withdraw/cancel
Differentiating: Transparency standards
Transformational: Manipulation protection

Definition: Government open data, data access, international data storage, data privacy and data protection
Opportunistic: Obligations applicable to each link of the data lifecycle (collection and processing, storage, transfer, and disposal)
Systematic: Cross-cutting obligations that apply to all links (responses to data breach, jurisdictional applicability, and rights of data subjects)
Differentiating: Central regulator
Transformational: Streamlined national and international compliance system

Definition: The relevant digital interventions for each country depend on the stage of digital readiness per pillar and sub-pillar
Basic: Basic foundations of digital transformation (particularly infrastructure and digital skills) are lacking hindering process for further stages
Opportunistic: Country is advancing in selected areas of digital transformation but without coordinated strategy
Systematic: Country is systematically advancing in key areas of digital transformation based on identified priority areas (e.g. skills, digital public services, etc.)
Differentiating: Country has clear strengths in digital transformation and foundational elements in place
Transformational: Country is advancing in all areas of national digital transformation based on an integrated strategy

Definition: Process for countries to become open & inclusive digital nations
Opportunistic: Information Technology Transformation
Systematic: Digital Transformation
Differentiating: Whole-of-Society Digital Transformation
Transformational: Inclusive Whole-of-Society Digital Transformation

Definition: Process and support for modernization
Opportunistic: Improving through modernization, urbanization, and industrialization
Systematic: Improving through support of skills, production capacity, and IT technologies
Differentiating: Leapfrogging: bypassing traditional stages of development by jumping directly into the latest technologies to pursue new opportunities
Transformational: Leapfrogging: bypassing traditional stages of development by jumping into alternative path of technological development involving emerging technologies with new benefits and new opportunities

Definition: The relevant digital interventions for each country depend on the stage of digital readiness per pillar and sub-pillar
Basic: Basic foundations of digital transformation (particularly infrastructure and digital skills) are lacking hindering process for further stages
Opportunistic: Country is advancing in selected areas of digital transformation but without coordinated strategy
Systematic: Country is systematically advancing in key areas of digital transformation based on identified priority areas (e.g. skills, digital public services, etc.)
Differentiating: Country has clear strengths in digital transformation and foundational elements in place
Transformational: Country is advancing in all areas of national digital transformation based on an integrated strategy
